fr:mainmatter.fr:p: The disjoint union is the coproduct in Set. Explicitly, the disjoint union of sets A and B is A \sqcup B = \{(a, 0) \mid a \in A\} \cup \{(b, 1) \mid b \in B\}, where \cup denotes the union.
A (pre)set is a collection of some pre-mathematical elements. We write x\in X to denote that x is an element of the set X.
A (set-)function consists of two sets, the domain and the codomain, and a rule (say, a derivation) that assigns to each element of the domain a unique element of the codomain.
The category of sets Set is the category whose objects are sets and whose morphisms are set-functions.

fr:title.text: Elementary theory of the category of sets

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Elementary theory of the category of sets

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Lawvere's elementary theory of the category of sets asserts that the category of sets is the well-pointed topos with choice and a natural numbers object.
An injection is a monomorhpism in Set. Explicitly, a map A\xrightarrow {f} B is injective if, for every x,y\in A, f(x)=f(y) implies x=y.
An surjection is an epimorphism in Set. Explicitly, a map A\xrightarrow {f} B is surjective if, for every y\in B, there exists an x\in A such that f(x)=y.
A bijection is an isomorphism in Set. Explicitly, a map is bijective if it is both injective and surjective.
A subset is a subobject in Set. Notationally, it is specified as \{x\in X: \phi (x)\}, where \phi (x) is the classifying map of the subobject.
The empty set \varnothing is the initial object in Set. Explicitly, it is the set with no elements.
The singleton set * is the terminal object in Set. Explicitly, it is the set with one element.
The cartesian product is the product in Set. Explicitly, the product of sets A and B is A\times B = \{(a, b) \mid a\in A, b\in B\}.
The disjoint union is the coproduct in Set. Explicitly, the disjoint union of sets A and B is A \sqcup B = \{(a, 0) \mid a \in A\} \cup \{(b, 1) \mid b \in B\}, where \cup denotes the union.
An equivalence relation is a congruence in Set. Explicitly, it is a reflexive, symmetric, and transitive relation.
The quotient of a set X by an equivalence relation \sim is the set of equivalence classes of \sim , i.e. \{\{x: x\sim x_0\}: x_0\in X\}.
Set is complete.

By the completeness criterion, it suffices to give products and equalizers. Products are given by the cartesian product. The equalizer of functions A\overset {f,g}{\rightrightarrows }B is \{a\in A: f(a) = b(a)\}.

Let J\xrightarrow {D} Set be a small diagram. We define \operatorname *{lim} D = \operatorname *{Cone}_D(*) = \operatorname {Hom}(*, D), where * is the constant functor at the singleton and \operatorname *{Cone} is the cone functor. Note that this is indeed a set, because J is small. An element of this set is a natural transformation *\xrightarrow {\mu } D, which consists of a morphism *\xrightarrow {\mu _j} Dj for each j\in J, hence canonically identifies a J-tuple of elements (x_i\in Dj). The legs of should be maps \operatorname *{lim} D\xrightarrow {\lambda } Dj; we define these by (*\xrightarrow {\mu } D)\xmapsto {\lambda _j} \mu _j(*).

To show that this cone is limiting, let Z\xrightarrow {
u } D be a cone. We need to show that 
u factors uniquely through \lambda . An element z\in Z identifies a map *	o Z, and hence a cone *	o Z\xrightarrow {
u } D, which is thus an element t(z)\in \operatorname *{lim} D. Now \lambda _j(t(z)) = (
u z)_j = 
u _j(z), and so 
u = \lambda t, as desired. It remains to show uniqueness, but any function Z\xrightarrow {u} \operatorname *{lim} D factoring 
u must satisfy u(z)_j = \lambda _j(u(z)) = 
u _j(z) = (
u z)_j = t(z)_j, so we are done.
Set is cocomplete.

By the cocompleteness criterion, it suffices to give coproducts and coequalizers. Coproducts are given by the disjoint union. The coequalizer of functions A\overset {f,g}{\rightrightarrows } B is B / \sim , where \sim is the equivalence relation generated by f(a) \sim g(a) for all a \in A, and / denotes the quotient of sets.
An epimorphism of groups is just a surjective homomorphism.
First, if G\xrightarrow {e} H is a surjective homomorphism, then given homomorphisms H\overset {f, g}{\rightrightarrows } K, we have that f = g because e is an epi in Set, so e is an epi.

Second, let G\xrightarrow {e} H be an epi in Grp. We wish to find a group K and two maps H\overset {f, g}{\rightrightarrows } K which agree on the image of e, hence are equal, in such a way that their equality allows us to conclude surjectivity of e. Let K be the symmetric group of the set of cosets H/e(G) with an adjoined point *.

Let H\xrightarrow {f} K be the map which sends h\in H to the associated permutation acting on kH by left translation and fixing *. Let \sigma \in K be the permutation which exchanges e(G) and *; let g be f composed with the inner automorphism associated to \sigma .

We finally claim that f(e(a)) = g(e(a)) for each a\in G. Indeed, since e(a)\in e(G), e(a) fixes e(G) and *, so is fixed under conjugation by \sigma . Now since e is an epi, f = g. Thus for each b\in H, f(b) = g(b), so that g(b) fixes f(H), i.e. bf(H) = f(H), so b\in f(H), as desired.

A sieve is a subfunctor of a contravariant hom-functor. Explicitly, a sieve S on x\in C consists of a collection of maps with codomain x that is closed under precomposition, i.e. if z\xrightarrow {f}x\in S and z'\xrightarrow {g} z is any map, then fh\in S.
Set is cocomplete.

By the cocompleteness criterion, it suffices to give coproducts and coequalizers. Coproducts are given by the disjoint union. The coequalizer of functions A\overset {f,g}{\rightrightarrows } B is B / \sim , where \sim is the equivalence relation generated by f(a) \sim g(a) for all a \in A, and / denotes the quotient of sets.
A coproduct is a colimit of a discrete diagram. Its colegs are called coprojections.
A morphism in a category is an endomorphism if its domain and codomain agree.
This note is still to do.
